reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed this book. The author is a good writer and did a great job of describing the view, conditions, and all of the pain he endured. With the right budget this would make a great movie.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Nice depictions of the Canadian terrain and weather as the team forged through the waterways of Northern Canada.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Amazing book in many ways. A vision of another world and its residents in all its spectacular beauty and wildness in what is like an artists eye. I feel like in a way I was taken along on the journey myself! An almost unbelievable survival story ensues.

reviews.reviewerName: Nancy East, author of Chasing the Smokies Moon
reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Compelling rite of passage
reviews.reviewText: I bought this book for my teenage son, Aidan, but it sat collecting dust on his nightstand. He’d rather be outdoors doing rather than inside reading. I guess I shouldn’t complain. I found it one day while cleaning his room (which I will complain about) and read the first few pages to see if it captured my attention. They did, and it easily found its way on my list of favorites.The Twenty-Ninth Day is a powerful coming-of-age story. Alex Messenger was 17 years old when he set out to canoe 700 miles in the remote Canadian wilderness with friends and an adult mentor. On the twenty-ninth day of the trip, he was attacked by a grizzly bear. Clearly, he survived to tell the tale, and what a gift he has for telling it.The only thing I know about canoeing is from a crazy escapade of rescuing an abandoned one in the Smokies. So I suspected the story might bore me until the attack. I also wondered if the book would make me more fearful for my kids on adventures they take apart from me, especially Aidan who is now eighteen and spreading his wings to fly further away by the day.On both counts, I was proven wrong. It made me want more adventures like this for my kids, despite the inherent risks. The story is a bold testament to the benefits of exposing youth to experiences outside of their comfort zone, especially if it puts them in the natural world sans a computer screen.Alex’s writing style is a bit Heminway-esque to me. Not in a one-syllable kind of way, but in the uncluttered yet descriptive prose he uses to describe the setting, story and his emotions. Not to mention he’s just a cool, old soul kind of kid (now adult) who was wise beyond his years at the formative age when these events occurred.Finally, as a search and rescue team member, this book held special interest for me in how the group handled Alex’s attack. I won’t give anything away, but I will say I wish everyone was as level-headed and prepared in the event of a true backcountry emergency. This would be a fantastic book to discuss and debate with my teammates and outdoor enthusiast friends.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2023
reviews.reviewText: First half was much more interesting than the second. Felt like they struggled to fill pages after the attack. And the reasoning to not get him out of there and into the hands of professionals made no sense to me.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Good read and well written. A few missed parts of his trip, but understandable due to situation.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not too gripping.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I really found myself captivated by this book! It is extremely well written -- so much so that I had to keep reminding myself that this was written by a young man of seventeen, still in high school. He writes better than many adults -- and has the emotional maturity of someone years older. I am many years older than Alex but I don't know if I could have even convinced myself to go on such a trip -- much less be able to handle myself so well when face to face with an angry bear in a harsh wilderness environment! The story of these young men navigating many miles of northern wilderness, by canoe and facing stormy weather, wild animals, food shortage, a lost canoe and more is inspiring and captivating. This would also make an excellent movie.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 5, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Great book, really enjoyed it. Very graphic.
This story kept me on the edge of my seat!

reviews.reviewTitle: First hand accounts are always enlightening and interesting.
reviews.reviewText: This is told in forensic detail by a young adventurer travelling the wild reaches of Canada on a guided adventure. His ordeal from a bear attack reveals just how much damage a non lethal attack can do. The reality of infection from animal bites is also made clear. All in all it was a sustaining narrative of a young man's encounter with the wild, a rare thing as the world's wilderness has become more mysterious. A worthy book to read.
Colourful explanations of the nature encountered - made it real. Such calm given the circumstances for a young man - now truly a real man.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 27, 2020
reviews.reviewText: Great book. Easy to read and it feels like your on the journey. You will feel cold and damp just reading about this trip. The bear attack is gripping and horrifying. You won’t be able to put it down.
